But it seemed like a nice funfact, something, you would never come in contact with here in Germany. Until last year. My partner found a dead "big fly" (Musca domestica?), sitting on the wall of the kitchen. He thought, that it looked quite interesting since it had these large white stripes at the abdomen and conserved it in alcohol.
When he tried to identify the species, he realized, that this fly had died due to the fungus. However, at this time, we also had a Drosophila "invasion" and we hoped, that they might get infected.
Nope, it seems, that this funghi was only specialised on big flies.

So far only insects are known to have this kind of fungus control them. Part of it is because of how simple their brains are. Insect brains are extremely simple- some insects can operate without them. Most insects have ganglia, or nerve clusters, that control their legs and wings, and their sensory organs like antennae can be directly connected to the ganglia, skipping their brain entirely. This means insects don't really use their brains for much, unlike us, and so controlling insects brains has evolved independently not just in fungi but in venom too, because it's relatively easy to do

As a student of agriculture, I can confidently say there is no chance of entomophagic fungi undergoing a zoonotic event to humans. Parasitoids like these fungi are highly specific in targets, only being able to attack one species or genus. To mutate to attack humans would require many mutations that would reduce that fungus' fitness. The specificity of fungal parasitoids also means any epidemics can be contained.

Wow! Amazing! It's similar to cordyceps that attach to ants and other insects. The difference, though, is instead of the insect taking root and "summiting", it can still move around with the fungus steadily growing. Eventually, the insect will grow "spore horns" and die. Unlike the fruitfly, the fungus grows from everywhere; not just the abdomen. Each insect has its own species of cordyceps so a spore from cordyceps that grow on ants won't germinate on beetles and vice versa. Nature is so amazing...
